com.salesforce.omakase.ast

Class AbstractSyntax

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.salesforce.omakase.ast.AbstractSyntax
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Syntax, Broadcastable, Writable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    AbstractAtRuleMember, AbstractGroupable, PropertyName, PropertyValue, RawFunction, RawSyntax, Stylesheet

    public abstract class AbstractSyntax
extends Object
implements Syntax
    Base class for Syntax units.

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      AbstractSyntax()
      Creates a new instance with no line or number specified (used for dynamically created Syntax units).
      AbstractSyntax(int line, int column)
      Creates a new instance with the given line and column numbers.

      • copiedFrom

        protected final <T extends Syntax> T copiedFrom(T original)
        This should be called on all copied units. It handles shared logic such as copying comments.

        Examples: 

        
     Rule copy = new Rule().copiedFrom(original);
        Type Parameters:
        T - Syntax type.
        Parameters:
        original - The original, copied unit.
        Returns:
        this, for chaining.

      • comment

        public Syntax comment(String comment)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Adds the given comment to this unit.

        Note that in the case of Selectors, it is preferred to add comments to the Selector object itself instead of the individual SimpleSelectors inside of it. Likewise, it is preferred to add a comment to the Declaration itself instead of the property name or value inside of it.

        Specified by:
        comment in interface Syntax

      • comments

        public com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList<Comment> comments()
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Gets all comments associated with this Syntax unit.

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For more info, see the main readme file.

        Specified by:
        comments in interface Syntax
        Returns:
        The list of comments. Never returns null.

      • orphanedComments

        public com.google.common.collect.ImmutableList<Comment> orphanedComments()
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Gets all orphaned comments (comments that appear after or at the end of the unit).

        A comment is considered orphaned if it does not appear before a logically associated unit. For example, comments at the end of a stylesheet or declaration block.

        Specified by:
        orphanedComments in interface Syntax
        Returns:
        The list of comments. Never returns null.

      • hasAnnotation

        public boolean hasAnnotation(String name)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Checks if this unit has a CSS comment annotation with the given name.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For convenience, the Rule will check the comments on the first Selector for annotation getter methods (which includes this method). For more info, see the main readme file.

        Specified by:
        hasAnnotation in interface Syntax
        Parameters:
        name - Check for an annotation with this name.
        Returns:
        True if a CssAnnotation was found with the given name in Comments associated with this unit.

      • hasAnnotation

        public boolean hasAnnotation(CssAnnotation annotation)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Checks if this unit has a CSS comment with a CssAnnotation that equals the given one.

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For convenience, the Rule will check the comments on the first Selector for annotation getter methods though, including this method. For more info, see the main readme file.

        This is most useful in tangent with the Syntax.annotate(CssAnnotation) method. You can annotate many syntax units using that method and then subsequently check for the annotation using this method, reusing the same instance in all cases for efficiency.

        The annotation must match according to the rules defined in CssAnnotation.equals(Object).

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For convenience, the Rule will check the comments on the first Selector for annotation getter methods (which includes this method). For more info, see the main readme file.

        Specified by:
        hasAnnotation in interface Syntax
        Parameters:
        annotation - Check for a CssAnnotation that equals this one.
        Returns:
        True if a CssAnnotation was found that equals the given one.

      • annotation

        public Optional<CssAnnotation> annotation(String name)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Gets the CssAnnotation with the given name from the comments associated with this unit, if there is one.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For convenience, the Rule will check the comments on the first Selector for annotation getter methods (which includes this method). For more info, see the main readme file.

        Specified by:
        annotation in interface Syntax
        Parameters:
        name - Get the annotation with this name.
        Returns:
        The CssAnnotation, or an empty Optional if not found.

      • annotations

        public List<CssAnnotation> annotations()
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Gets all CssAnnotations from the comments associated with this unit.

        CSS comment annotations are CSS comments that contain an annotation in the format of "@annotationName [optionalArgs]", for example "@noparse", "@browser ie7", etc...

        Only one annotation per comment block is allowed.

        A unit is associated with all comments that directly precede it. However in the case of comments at the start of a Rule, the first Selector will contain the comment, not the Rule or the SimpleSelector. For convenience, the Rule will check the comments on the first Selector for annotation getter methods (which includes this method). For more info, see the main readme file.

        Specified by:
        annotations in interface Syntax
        Returns:
        All found CssAnnotations.

      • annotate

        public void annotate(CssAnnotation annotation)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Appends the given CssAnnotation to this unit.

        A Comment will be created and appended to this unit using the normal CSS comment annotation syntax. This means if CSS comments are written out then they will include this annotation. The comment will also be returned by normal comment retrieval methods such as Syntax.comments().

        You can subsequently check for this annotation again using the Syntax.hasAnnotation(CssAnnotation) method. This might be useful in plugins that dynamically annotate syntax units and then subsequently check for the annotation later on, as using both of these methods can efficiently reuse the same CssAnnotation instance.

        Specified by:
        annotate in interface Syntax
        Parameters:
        annotation - Append this annotation.

      • annotateUnlessPresent

        public void annotateUnlessPresent(CssAnnotation annotation)
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Same as Syntax.annotate(CssAnnotation), except only if Syntax.hasAnnotation(CssAnnotation) is false for the given annotation.

        Note that if using this method on a Rule that comments at the start of a Rule are usually associated with the Selector, and this method will not check the Selector when determining if the annotation is present. Thus you should only call this method on a Rule if you are sure the annotation was manually added to the Rule.

        Specified by:
        annotateUnlessPresent in interface Syntax
        Parameters:
        annotation - Add this annotation.

      • status

        public void status(Status status)
        Description copied from interface: Broadcastable
        Sets the current broadcast status. Normally for internal use. Do not call without understanding the implications.
        Specified by:
        status in interface Broadcastable
        Parameters:
        status - The new status.

      • status

        public Status status()
        Description copied from interface: Broadcastable
        Gets the current broadcast status of this unit.

        This primarily determines whether this unit should be broadcasted again.

        Specified by:
        status in interface Broadcastable
        Returns:
        The current broadcast status.

      • propagateBroadcast

        public void propagateBroadcast(Broadcaster broadcaster,
                               Status status)
        Description copied from interface: Broadcastable
        Broadcasts or rebroadcasts all child units using the given Broadcaster.

        The broadcast will only occur for a unit if its Status matches the given Status.

        Implementers should call this on child units and SyntaxCollections first, then use the broadcaster to broadcast itself. All of this should be wrapped in a check to ensure the Status matches.

        Specified by:
        propagateBroadcast in interface Broadcastable
        Parameters:
        broadcaster - Use this Broadcaster to broadcast all unbroadcasted child units.
        status - Broadcast units that have this status.

      • breakBroadcast

        public boolean breakBroadcast(SubscriptionPhase phase)
        Description copied from interface: Broadcastable
        Gets whether an in-progress broadcast should be stopped.

        This might be true if a change of state or conditions of the unit result in the broadcast no longer being necessary during the given SubscriptionPhase.

        Specified by:
        breakBroadcast in interface Broadcastable
        Parameters:
        phase - The current SubscriptionPhase.
        Returns:
        True if in-progress broadcasting should be stopped.

      • isWritable

        public boolean isWritable()
        Description copied from interface: Writable
        Returns whether this unit should actually be written.

        Usually this should just return true, however some units that are detachable or otherwise potentially invalid should first check their state and respond appropriately.

        Specified by:
        isWritable in interface Writable
        Returns:
        True if the unit should be written.

      • writesOwnComments

        public boolean writesOwnComments()
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Specifies whether this object will handle writing its own comments, instead of the automatic behavior of the StyleWriter.

        If returning true, be sure to check StyleWriter.shouldWriteAllComments() to determine if comments should actually be written out or not. The StyleWriter.appendComments(Iterable, StyleAppendable) utility method contains this logic and is the preferable way to handle it.

        Specified by:
        writesOwnComments in interface Syntax
        Returns:
        True if this object writes its own comments.

      • writesOwnOrphanedComments

        public boolean writesOwnOrphanedComments()
        Description copied from interface: Syntax
        Specifies whether this object will handle writing its own orphaned comments, instead of the automatic behavior of the StyleWriter.

        If returning true, be sure to check StyleWriter.shouldWriteAllComments() to determine if comments should actually be written out or not. The StyleWriter.appendComments(Iterable, StyleAppendable) utility method contains this logic and is the preferable way to handle it.

        Specified by:
        writesOwnOrphanedComments in interface Syntax
        Returns:
        True if this object writes its own comments.
